content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												A unique fantasy RPG with a focus on Chinese martial arts, Jade Empire is BioWare's follow-up to Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic. Largely the same game functionally, Jade Empire feels a bit weaker in story and character depth, but is still quite a memorable adventure. The graphics are beautiful to look at, and the core Action/RPG gameplay has a nice sense of variety.(Rating: 8/10 "Very good")

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												This is a borderline positive recommendation, for a number of reasons.The story as a whole is good, but dissapointing. It is a very predictable story. You are a student to a great, but unknown master with a dark past that wants to keep you safe until the hand of destiny itself sets you on a path to restore balance in the empire. There is a twist that feels telegraphed and a bit of mystery surrounding one of the characters that gives itself away before you're even two hourse in, if you're paying attention. It is short, but in this case it's a good thing, as the story is so generic it would feel like wading through a pool of undried cement. At just about 25 hours, give or take, it paces itself rather well and is coherent, but for a game with conversation options, it's extremely linear, especially once you enter the fortress. The biggest let down is the conversations. Each conversation you are given a number of lines you can choose which amount to nothing unless it's an obvious good vs. evil type of choice. Each character you speak to reacts almost the same way and says the same things regardless of your answer, with some exceptions with the three romance options (two per gender). Also, every important character that you encounter more often than once will repeat themselves almost endlessly. In one conversation I had with the Water Dragon, she told me the same thing no less than seven times, to the detriment of my already dying brain. The combat is, well, annoying. On one hand it's dynamic, keeping you involved in every fight, which is a good thing. On the other hand it's repetitive and even outright annoying. Your attacks have this bothersome ability of knocking back the enemy you are attacking just out of reach of your next attack, unless you pin them to the edge of the fight zone. Fast styles are almost hands down superior to any slower style because each attack interrupts your enemy (unless they are a massive enemy like the toad or elephant demons or the jade golems). The mechanics of each enemy, while interesting at first become a nuisance the further you go into the story, especially ghosts.There is one mini game (thankfully) in the game, but I won't go into it as you can effectively skip all of it unless you want to finish a character's quest line. The other ones are useless, or next to.The redeeming quality is the game's companion characters. For a short game they are rather one dimensional but interesting enough to last you the first half of the game after which you won't get anything more than remarks out of them, with the exception of your romance option. They will comment as you adventure and then when you all group up again will act like they were just then hearing about what was happening for the first time. However, they are colorful and fit very well within their one dimension, fleshing it out very well. I understand that the review seems rather negative, but I rather enjoyed the game, with some glaring exceptions. Jade Empire is akin to that somewhat annoying dinner guest, who is pleasant enough company but you can't quite wait for them to leave, as much as you might wish to feel otherwise.Overall this is a game that, in my opinion, desperately needs a sequel to redeem itself. I recommend it, but only barely. If you are looking to play an action game with a modicum of morality and interaction, this would fit quite well, but if you are looking for an actual rpg, this would not fit that bill

There is a twist that feels telegraphed and a bit of mystery surrounding one of the characters that gives itself away before you're even two hourse in, if you're paying attention. It is short, but in this case it's a good thing, as the story is so generic it would feel like wading through a pool of undried cement. At just about 25 hours, give or take, it paces itself rather well and is coherent, but for a game with conversation options, it's extremely linear, especially once you enter the fortress. The biggest let down is the conversations. Each conversation you are given a number of lines you can choose which amount to nothing unless it's an obvious good vs. evil type of choice. Each character you speak to reacts almost the same way and says the same things regardless of your answer, with some exceptions with the three romance options (two per gender). Also, every important character that you encounter more often than once will repeat themselves almost endlessly. In one conversation I had with the Water Dragon, she told me the same thing no less than seven times, to the detriment of my already dying brain. The combat is, well, annoying. On one hand it's dynamic, keeping you involved in every fight, which is a good thing. On the other hand it's repetitive and even outright annoying. Your attacks have this bothersome ability of knocking back the enemy you are attacking just out of reach of your next attack, unless you pin them to the edge of the fight zone. Fast styles are almost hands down superior to any slower style because each attack interrupts your enemy (unless they are a massive enemy like the toad or elephant demons or the jade golems). The mechanics of each enemy, while interesting at first become a nuisance the further you go into the story, especially ghosts.There is one mini game (thankfully) in the game, but I won't go into it as you can effectively skip all of it unless you want to finish a character's quest line. The other ones are useless, or next to.The redeeming quality is the game's companion characters. For a short game they are rather one dimensional but interesting enough to last you the first half of the game after which you won't get anything more than remarks out of them, with the exception of your romance option. They will comment as you adventure and then when you all group up again will act like they were just then hearing about what was happening for the first time. However, they are colorful and fit very well within their one dimension, fleshing it out very well. I understand that the review seems rather negative, but I rather enjoyed the game, with some glaring exceptions. Jade Empire is akin to that somewhat annoying dinner guest, who is pleasant enough company but you can't quite wait for them to leave, as much as you might wish to feel otherwise.Overall this is a game that, in my opinion, desperately needs a sequel to redeem itself. 												The game itself, I heartily recommend. Just don't play this port.First off, you can't play it unless you're running Steam as an administrator. Which wouldn't be that bad, if not for the fact that /I literally cannot continue playing due to a bug/.I completed over half the game, then BAM. In order to finish a quest, I need to fight someone (as it usually goes in the Jade Empire). The moment combat starts, however, the map /breaks/, and it becomes literally impossible to win the fight (it also becomes impossible to lose the fight, on that note).This is a great game, but I can't recommend it on Steam. Do yourself a favor, and don't buy this. You'll be saving yourself the frustration.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Jade Empire is Bioware's most forgetable RPG.  That doesn't make it bad, but there is a reason the developer turned Mass Effect and Dragon Age into trilogies and we haven't heard a word about Jade Empire 2.Paradoxically, this is also Bioware's most unique RPG.  It is a martial arts RPG set in a high fantasy world inspired by Chinese folklore.  The combat animations are very good, creating using motion capture technology of actual martial arts professionals.Here's the problem: the combat is bad.  For a game with a heavy focus on combat, that is very problematic.  The animations look great, but as a player all you do is push a few buttons to either: quick attack, power attack, block, or area attack.  While the player can obtain other styles, almost everything combat has to offer in the game is experienced in the tutorial.  Combat then becomes a routine affair of whitling down enemy health while jumping around trying to avoid damage.  Pro tip: don't use the "Thousand Cuts" style, as a result of its animation timing (seriously), it is notably inferior to the other starting styles.More problematic: character creation is incredibly linear.  As you level up, your Health, Chi, and Focus increase.  You then can assign 3 points to either Health, Chi, or Focus.  Pro Tip: Chi is probably the best option.  Meaning, multiple playthroughs will feel very similar to each other.  Still, the game does have a story similar to other Bioware hits.  If you liked Knights of the Old Republic and Mass Effect for the story, you will enjoy this game for the story alone.  It is suitably epic, has a pretty big twist towards the end, and frankly there is nothing else quite like this game.  The characters are well written, and Henpecked Ho and Black Wirlwind provide good comic relief.  Protip: For combat, just use Dawn Star's support mode, which replenishes Chi.

												This game is truly a really great game. It is a brilliant game that is just beautiful. I absolutely loved it on the xbox and was overjoyed to find it here on steam. I would truly love nothing more than to highly recommend it to anyone and everyone... Sadly though I can not as it does not work on steam nor does it look like that will change anytime in the near future. There are a few lucky souls who after hours upon hours of tinkering have gotten this game to work for them... Sadly though they are a very, very, very small percent. If your PC happen to be running anything remotely new do not expect this game to work. Expect to see many, many "Failed to find steam" messages. I bought this game back in March and I have tinkered with it for countless hours, have tried every work around that exists on the internet and have yet to see it work. IF this game ever gets fixed (and that is looking like a very big IF)... IF by some miracle this game ever does happen to get fixed I would highly recommend it but at this point that looks like it will never happen. For now save your money and buy something that actually works. Valve, EA, and BioWare really dropped the ball on this amazing game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												This game is without the shred of doubt one of the best bioware games this man has played in his lifetime. The story is just a rich flowing river of awesomeness that never ends. There are many twists and turns that are sure to grab audiences by the thousand. The story alone should be a reason to buy this game as it is something Bioware is famed for and this is just fantastic. A standard good and evil choice, though it is described differently in a way. I must say it knows how to make these conflicting choices enjoyable at times, while making us feel like♥♥♥♥♥♥♥doing it. It was a true marvel. The combat and the fighting styles this game presents are simply amazing, they go very well with their surroundings and are unique in any given situation. The chi function brought out is a worthy life saver. Altogether this game is a classic titan among its genre. Talking about it is one thing, playing it is what needs to happen. In reference to its negative reputation on steam: Yes there are issues getting the game to work, but the community has sorted those concerns out. More or less. While i originally believed i had wasted my time and money i in fact bypassed the issue with help. IT is well worth its price, you just have to be patient.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												I first played Jade Empire on the original xbox and was mesmerized and enchanted by the bold, beautiful interpretation of Ancient China presented in the game. I was so hyped reading previews for it that I bought the game the day it came out because I knew it was going to be an awesome and the company who created it had a great track record at the time.  It was made by Bioware in their heyday back when all they had was Baldur's Gate, Neverwinter Nights, and KOTOR under their belts. It had a fantastic story, interesting characters, a morality system and fun, intuitive fighting system that was easy to pick up. Pretty much everything people loved about KOTOR with a better combat system and a original setting. If there was IP that I wish Bioware would pick back up, it would be Jade Empire. If this game is on sale, GET IT! If not, 10 dollars isn't bad for all the content and fun that you can get. The only complaint that I have about this version as that with a lot of older games there are some compatbility issues with later OS. A small hindrance and is easily remedied with some tinkering. If you have never played this game or don't own it, and you are even remotely interested in the setting, GET THIS GAME!! 10/10

content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												for all these people claming the game is broken there is a simple fix that i will post in this comment because i got the cant find steam problem and when i did this it worked just fine and it saves u all are welcome in the future:) If the config tool fails to launch with a "Can't find Steam" error message, simply restarting Steam should fix that.If the issue persists or the config tool freezes at one point while gathering system information on your first launch, try the following;Locate the JadeEmpireConfig file in the game's Steam folder (usually found at C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Jade Empire)Right click, select properties, select compatibility and set it to compatibility mode for Windows Vista SP2.If this fails to fix the freeze, you must do the following;Using notepad, create a blank text file.Name it SystemInformation.xml and save it in the data folder inside the Jade Empire folder (usually found at C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Jade Empire\data).Copy the Steam.dll file from the base Steam folder (C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam) and paste it into the Jade Empire folder (C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Jade Empire - NOT the data folder).Information This will effectively bypass the config tool which should allow you to launch the game.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												So I'm here to tell it like it is, because honestly I doubt anyone will; this game is OK. No, it's not "great," but it's extremely good at what it does; you feel flighty and free in combat. So let's do a simplified list because otherwise people won't read past the first sentence:Pros:1) A variety of both martial and magical styles in the vanilla version -- this allows for several concepts to take shape with each different playthrough, such as a sword-wielding maniac that uses fire to immolate his foes2) Pleasing visual styles -- the forms look graceful or rough as it is appropriate. Dodging is one of the most enjoyable aspects of the game due to how light your character will feel; it is almost as if you have wings in combat. The lighting is also gorgeous in several areas, and that really brings out the beauty of the pseudo-Chinese architecture. 3) Replayability -- if you beat the game, you have the option of doing a new game + through the Jade Master mode. 4) Intriguing lore and setting -- Jade Empire has beautiful bestiary entires and journals scattered throughout the world in the form of culture-appropriate scrolls or books. Much of the history inside the game, including that of the creatures, is highly stimulating. Cons (buckle up):1) Extremely repetitive gameplay -- while the game looks and feels fantastic, the simplistic combat mechanics become almost laborous after a few hours into the game, ESPECIALLY against some of the mush more difficult opponents. Eventually it boils down to mashing on an enemy for several seconds until they die, which in Jade Master mode becomes minutes. The only saving grace to this is the ability to swiftly slaughter small-scale enemies with the Harmonic Combos in the game. Unfortunately, this also means that everything eventually guides you towards taking a few specific styles just to progress in a sane way.2) Copy and Paste enemies -- this is a tiny con. You'll find yourself running into the same enemies using the same styles and the same heads but on slightly different bodies. BioWare games are notorious for this re-use of content to fill gaps, but here it feels quite coarse; enemies are far too similar, even into the latter half of the game. When you see elite guards using the same poking spear that the peasents wielded in the start of the game, we have a problem.3) Strength of styles -- it's obvious the team did a ton of balance before they finished this (not), so you'll be left tossing your favorite style in the trash if it's not one of the top tier, otherwise you'll run into a ton of issues in the harder fights or in Jade Master (which is seriously going to test how well you know your combos and styles). 4) Lack of character development/Lack of interesting characters -- I'll be honest here, I thought almost every companion you could get turned out to be 1-dimensional. At least in KotOR I cared about several of the allies working with me, but here everything feels far too stiff. The only character I found interesting was the ridiculous comedic relief. It just feels so forced.The game is fun if you can look past some of the defects and appreciate it for what it is: a kung-fu beat-em-up with a paper-thin story and paper-thin characters. People put this game near the bottom of the BioWare list and it definitely earns its spot, however...A certain modder (may she be blessed) has created one of the most fantastic modifications for this game I have ever seen: Jade Empire in Style. It does everything right; character skins, new styles, new combat mechanics, better combos, more combos, more enemies, etc. It's fantastic. It doesn't try to fix anything broken with the story or characters, it builds on the game's strength--the Kung Fu. And holy cow does it do it well! Here's a link to the modder's site if you're interested in expanding your Jade Empire experience: http://jade-empire-in-style.com/

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												(even though Steams shows I only played half an hour of the game, the truth is I finished it several years ago)This game is simply amazing. It has something to offer for everyone; fast-paced and fun combat, great story, interesting characters, RPG elements, fun "minigames" (for lack of a better word), possible relationships with other characters (and especially Sky). The graphics don't look as amazing as they seemed several years ago, but the visual side is still pleasant to look at and very characteristic. What made this game one of my favourites was the story. Even though it may seem a bit boring at the beginning, soon the story grips you and doesn't let go until you finish the game. Not only you visit interesting locations and meet various people (who actually seem like real characters and not just something generated for a game), you also make significant choices that affect the game's ending. The last element I would like to mention is the combat. As for my character, I chose the Leaping Tiger style and after upgrading it to maximum, I think it's the best I could have chosen, maybe with an exception of Crimson Tears, but they require a lot of focus. But I loved the way you could learn new styles (Drunken Fist was hilarious) and that you could choose how your companion would support you (active/passive). The only downside to this game is that the Steam version is somewhat buggy. In my case, the game was in slow motion. I managed to solve the issue, though I can't remember how. If you're unsure whether you would like this game, I recommend waiting for a Steam sale. If it's below 5 euro, you won't regret getting it.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2013
												Jade Empire - An often over-looked gemThrown into a chaotic world full of different factions, you choose which path will you follow: the open palm or the closed fist. Before you uncover the truth about what goes on and what's your role in it, you will have to travel through cities, valleys, forests, swamps, caves and mountains, meeting interesting characters on every corner.Even though the main focus of the game is story, the action-based combat doesn't lag behind and is enriched with different weapon tactics, various techniques and (eventually) transmorphing into mythical beings during fights. The only problem is, there doesn't seem to be enough time to really try these out, since by the time you collect most of them, the game is nearly over.Jade Empire implements the aesthetic and mythology of the far east while building an intricate, believable world with great characters, mesmerizing environments and exciting quests. The ideas, characters and concepts woven into the game make it a beautiful place rich with detail. I want more!V e r d i c t : AWESOMESAUCE, which means nearly perfect

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												Wow, I am amazed at this gem of a game. Once again Bioware doesn't dissapoint with their masterful storytelling, plot and gameplay.Graphically, this special edition has improved the textures of the original and added in extra features not present in the original game. Even though the game is years old, the atmosphere is colorful and vivid with very well done asian influenced concepts.In the gameplay department, the controls are a bit stiff even when playing with the gamepad. Controls are very much like "The Legend Of Zelda", everything is in real time and most enemies will gang up on you. Red bar is obviously health, Blue bar is for healing, magic attack or add damage to physical attack, Yellow bar is for weapon or bullet time.I highly recommend this game to people who enjoy Bioware games and/or people who are into games with a near perfect blend of story and gameplay. People say this game is short, but that's only if you rush through it...Also...Storm Dragon is OP, it is so broken especially when maxed out...except for fighting ghosts, I hate fighting ghosts :(

content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												I never once looked forward to playing Jade Empire after the first time booting it.  Sure, it was serviceable enough of an RPG to keep me coming back until its conclusion but the game's flaws are too numerous and damaging to make it truely enjoyable or worthy of recommendation.  From its exposition-choked opening hours to its final moments which can be replayed quickly to achieve all possible endings, thus cheapening the experience, Jade Empire just feels weak and overwrought.  Dialogue is so ridiculously heavy and voice acting sometimes so poor that it had me angrily jamming my finger into the LMB repeatedly within ten minutes of starting the game.  Despite the game's insistence that I use various martial styles to deal with different combat situations, I rarely needed to do more than equip my longsword and spam the LMB in order to win fights.  Meh.  Jade Empire is clearly the result of a young Bioware biting off more than it can chew.  Add to this the fact that Bioware and Valve released a broken and unplayable version of this game onto Steam, requiring the consumer to do the necessary legwork to get it working and the result is a very resounding NO.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
												This game is... interesting. I purchased it upon recommendation from some friends. I was initially rather frustrated due to compatibility issues with modern machines - be warned, this game has some issues with Windows 8. If you are running W8, make sure you go into your SteamApps/common/Jade Empire folder, then run the "Jade Empire.exe" as an administrator - this usually fixes any issues you have with it. It also tends to be a bit disagreeable with dual monitors and alt-tabbing. The game itself is typical of BioWare, before they really solidified their RPG formula. It is very reminiscent of KOTOR, minus a lot of the polish. The story is fairly predictable and cliché - it's almost to the point where I startred treating it as a martial arts parody. The big "twist" can also be seen a mile away, and it wasn't all that great either. Generic good vs. evil morality system, characters are fairly flat and one-dimensional. Difficulty is all out of whack and oscillates with little predictability, with some fights being frustrating, and the majority being too easy. Overall, it's... okay. It's not great, but it isn't a bad game either. Definitely worth a try if you can pick it up on sale for cheap.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Bioware took a gamble with a fresh IP that brought not only an unusual setting but also a rather stark departure from conventional RPG combat mechanics. Unfortunately, what starts off as an intriguing world with some real challenge ultimately becomes a tedious and almost entirely linear slog.After finishing the obligatory tutorial area, the game's world opens up and you're free to indulge in a variety of side quests. While the writing is typical for a Bioware game, you'll encounter interesting scenarios and in some cases make unexpected (if not entirely nuanced) choices. The game uses a binary morality system, similar to Knights of the Old Republic, but the line between good and evil is not always as clear and sometimes it's best to take different routes if only to witness the most interesting results.Early on, the combat is challenging and you're encouraged to experiment with new styles--at times you're even forced to when facing enemies that are immune to certain types of attacks. It's a little clunky and doesn't hold a candle to proper action titles, but it works and is not really the focus of the game early on.Unfortunately, the final third of the game eschews this formula almost entirely. You're taken through several sequences of pretty much non-stop fighting, which is where the shortcomings of the combat system really become noticeable. Fights take too long to finish and you will most likely end up exploiting one or two strategies as surefire ways to take care of the onslaughts of enemies. Gone is the element of choice or character development -- you probably won't even feel the need to spend level-up points, given how easy the game becomes with just a few side quests under your belt. At this point in the game, it becomes very clear that the developers ran out of resources and hastily put together the final segments without much concern for the player. While the momentum had previously been building at a steady and satisfying rate, completing the journey becomes a chore. You're robbed of any real pay off.The game ran fine for me on Windows 10, barring the occaisional stuttering error, which were usually fixed with system reset. Technically, the game certainly shows its age, but the lackluster final act is what really undoes the whole thing. Unless you really like the idea of awkward real-time martial arts combat in an RPG, give this one a pass. Better games have come since its release.

If you ever wanted to play kung-fu-action-jesus-Shephard for a little bit, give it a go.

												So uh...this PC port does not start off well, basically being a broken product at a first impression. As far as I know you could have the best specs and still start the game unbelievably choppy in this build for whatever reason; yet behind the scenes you are still running at 30fps/60fps when scrolling the menu or seeing the clothes on your character react to the physics... Anyway, it's weird, it's unplayable, but I will tell you to get this game, for its merits of being one of Bioware's classics, and (most importantly) being able to fix this game within this first hour and half of me looking online and fiddling with stuff (which I believe anyone can do, thankfully). You're in your right to be discouraged from this since Steam basically put up an unbroken yet unplayable product, and just leave you there alone to figure it out, but in these easy steps I think you're guaranteed to have the game itself running as it should, and in less time to try and figure it like I had to:1. Go into your Environment Variables (easy way to pull it up is to search on the start menu and click "edit environment variables", but otherwise it is somewhere in the control panel), you'll see under "User variables for [your username]" there's a variable called "Path" - click on it, then click Edit. On the "variable value:" textbox, go to the very end of it (or hit "End" key), and copy/paste in the path of your Steam folder along with what is already there like this -;C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam ^it has to be seperated from the rest of the folder-paths starting with a semi-colon, and note this is an example, but usually your Steam folder should be in Program Files (x86) of your hard-drive - this will resolve the "Can't find Steam" error everytime you even try to start this game...2. The ONLY way to get rid of the chopping performance of the game is to go here - https://bitbucket.org/fk/jade-empire-stutter-fix/downloads - and download this zip folder, containing a Readme for instructions, a .dll file and C++ redistributable (vcredist_x86.exe). You simply extract the folder, and put those files in your Jade Empire folder (where your JadeEmpire.exe file is), and if you haven't installed the redistributable already (which usally comes with most games and already installed it for you) then do it again with this one supplied for you just in case. And all of this is verified and was tested on the GOG build of the game they are selling, so it should work for this build being sold by Steam.3...that's...actually it. You can do this in 2 minutes tops. Run the game from Steam and now it should work for you, from there you just see how it fairs on your computer, but considering it's an old game, the recommeded specs shouldn't be at all daunting. If it's still giving you a bit of trouble, you can right-click on the JadeEmpire.exe, go into Properties - Compatibility, run this in Windows XP compatibility mode, along with checking "Run as an administrator" and click Apply and try to run it again. Aside from that, you'll just have to figure out how your computer fairs with it personally, but the game itself should run properly and not flat-out broken for the customer. Hope everyone sees this at first glance when buying this game and get it running, just thought you might wanna' save some time and get right into playing this gem, or at least know what you're getting into before purchasing.--EDIT--I take it all back, fu-k this port...keeps crashing otherwise, well at least for me. If it's fine on your computer, god bless ya but I'm getting my refund right this minute. Really wanted to play this game. Thanks Steam...

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												So I understand this isn't exactly a popular review, and really that's to be expected whenever you're critical of a popular and acclaimed game.  Honestly, I was pretty angry when I originally wrote my review below, but now that I have a clear head, I wanted to clarify something:I dont' give a♥♥♥♥♥♥what your experience with this game was.MY experience was that this game was so agonizingly terrible that I didn't feel it was worth my time to keep playing long enough finish the tutorial.So if you ask me "Hey Dubhe14, would you like recommend this game or whatever just askin'"I'd be like "no, this game makes playing Too Human with beer goggles sound fun by comparison"The story was bad.  The combat was bad.  The game mechanics were bad.  Graphics were pretty alright considering its age, I can't really complain.  Dialogue was bad.  Characters were bland and uninteresting."well maybe dubee14 just sucks and is totally jellz that he wasn't good at this game like I am" betch I have nearly 200 hours on Dark Souls don't bring that "u jus suk" nonsense in here.Jade Empire is like your second playthrough of Knighs of the Old Republic, where you purposefully make all the bad choices just to be 100% evil, except they did it with design choices instead, and the result was a game that is 100% poop.------------------------------ORIGINAL REVIEW:I was really excited to play this game, since it gets unreal praise from everyone.  Too bad it's terrible.Combat:  This game has the most unintuitive, unengaging, clunky, button-mashing-dependant, wtf-was-that-unfair combat system I've ever seen in any game.  The combat system is built for 1-on-1 fights, but the game constantly pits you against 6 people at once, some of which will invariably be wielding weapons.  Since there are no area or sweeping attacks, and you're forced to damage one enemy at a time, this means you'll get surrouncded and stun-locked to death.  Oh, and wielding weapons depletes your "Focus" bar - when it gets empty, you are restricted from using weapons, a limit not placed on your enemies.Dodging: In the game options, you can change the dodge controls - you can have your character dodge when you double tap in a direction, or when you move in a direction while holding down "Block".  Choosing double-tap means your character will dodge forward whenever you change directions mid-run outside of combat - only forward, though, that's the only direction you're allowed to doge in outside of combat.  Needless to say, this gets very aggravating very quickly.Camera:  All the game's problems are exacerbated by the game's camera, which hovers right behind your character, but low enough that you can't see your hands.  This basically makes it impossible to judge how far away you are from an enemy, and whether you're close enough for your attack to hit.  It's a crap-shoot.  Easily fixable if you could angle the camera to one side, but it resets right away.Maybe it's a bad port to PC, and that's the reason for all these problems?  I can't belive this game came out 2 years after KOTOR, which had none of the issues above.  I can count on one hand how many games I've willingly abandoned, and now Jade Empire is part of that list, right next to Fable 3.  Maybe the story becomes AMAZING a few more hours in, but this game is absolute agony to play through - not worth it to me.

In this mult-award-winning action-RPG, your choices and actions will determine the fate of the entire Jade Empire. Will you prevent the destruction of this beautiful land, or will you crush it beneath your heel? Are you a warrior who uses his strength and fighting mastery to bring peace, or will you instead use your power to bring pain and ruin?The choice is yours.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2012
												Recommendation-This is a truly beautiful game, which presents a lovingly crafted and genuinely fascinating world, a host of fantastic characters and a great sense of freedom in terms of your actions in what is mostly a very polished package, and I happily recommend it to any PC gamer.Rough Plot-Jade Empire,  is loosely based on the legends of China - although Bioware has been careful to stress that it's not actually ancient China, which allows them to play around with all manner of elements ranging from geography to the inclusion of technology (often magic-powered) such as aircraft. Your character starts out as the star student of a martial arts school in a remote village, and in typical RPG style, you and your companions are quickly caught up in Much Bigger Things - to wit, the aforementioned ghouls, firebombings, and balance of heaven and earth - and sally forth to travel around the Jade Empire putting things right.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												April 2014.   I always wanted to play this game a long time ago ~2008...now I see it still selling on steam, so I give it a try since I have time now (2014)...It did not work for me recently in April 2014 and on windows 8 but still selling on steam.   Renaming the file to fix does not work either.But I found a fix on the net in one for the steam forum somewhere and related to other older games... Like the renaming fix, only the main exe works as workaround.    To fix, you need to add "steam" to your win8 environment PATH variable.Here's how for windows 8:1. control panel -> system icon -> Advanced system settings -> (this launch windows system properties)2. Advanced tab -> click on "environment variables" button.  (this launch environment variables user interface)3. on bottom section, inside system variables, select "PATH" variable from list.4. click edit button at bottom to edit PATH variable that you select above (3).5. append to variable value the text ";C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam;"  Make notice semicolon before and after and no blank space outside of ;click cancel to abort anytime.step 5 is important, do not mess up.  Or you may have to reinstall your computer.  Do not click okay until you are sure you did not mess up.   You can always come back and fix if you can retype the whole entire  string content from memory.   Click cancel to abort anytime.   Click okay when you are sure you did it right.  FYI: the entire string content is similar on most computer...you are fine if you make typo, just go back and edit.   Deleting and forgot entry is where re-install windows is a fix.  Here is what entire string content looks like on mine minus qoutes minus ":"C:\WINDOWS\system32;C:\WINDOWS;C:\WINDOWS\System32\Wbem;C:\WINDOWS\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\;C:\Program Files (x86)\ATI Technologies/ATI.ACE/Core-Static;C:/Users/Nhan/AppData/Local/Smartbar/Application/;C:/Program Files (x86)\Steam;"6. reboot computer to get environment path variable updated.?  play.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2012
												"I want to join the arena.""That's the spirit of the thing! Now, what name precedes you in your travels?""I am Egregious Prevaricator, respected scholar and grower of pipe weed. I'm shocked you haven't heard of me."Yes, you can actually adopt the name 'Egregious Prevaricator' as your arena name. This game was criticized by reviewers for its sub-par graphics and its quintessinally 'Bioware' story. But those reviewers completely overlooked the things that make the game one of the most memorable I've ever played. The colorful, vivid art style. The truly immersive, epic soundtrack. The fantastic Wuxia setting, completely novel in a cliched genre full of Lord of The Rings-esque elves and dwarves. The unforgettably nuanced characters. The riveting writing. The sense of a living, breathing world that broke conventions and boldly expanded the RPG genre.This game remains, to this day, my favorite Bioware artwork. Must buy.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												This game is KOTOR in Little big Chinatown. It's more homage to the Chinese Marital-art house asthetic than an RPG set in a faithflly re-created Ancient China, which will hit you as soon as the Steampunk technology comes into play.If you've played the Bioware Knights franchise, this game will feel right at home to you. The dialogue system, the alignment system, the influence over companions, etc. is all inherited from the 1st game.The only serious deviation is askewing of realtime-turn-based combat, for 3rd person combat. You click, and your character attacks, you can move and manuever your character at will.There is also a shoot-em' up mini-game which, at times I think clashes with the rest of the game in tone, but otherwise is memorable where most of BIoware's mini games were either boring or insufferable.Perhaps the most memorable feature to this game? The Cast. Alot of star power arrived for this outing, Nathan Fillion, Brian Doyle Murray, Armin Shimerman, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly John Cleese, and anyone whose played adapation titles like Devil May Cry or Final Fantasy 9 or Armored Core 4 will recognize Kari Wahlgren.I honestly can't recommend this game enough, but be warned, Imperfect Customer has it right, you do need to mess with some files inorder to get the game both to work, and for your cursor (the mouse pointer) to appear.If you're experiencing this problem download this file and put it into your Jade Empire directory:https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/22012712/JadeEmpireLauncher.exeIt's an old Jade Empire exe renamed "JadeEmpireLauncher" so steam will launch it instead of the launcher which can end in error. You still need to launch the game from Steam though, clicking on it won't do anything. Your Jade Empire Directory can be found in Steam-> SteamApps -> Common-> Jade Empire.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												If you like Bioware-style RPGs, definitely consider getting this game--especially if it's on sale. A lot of folks have been complaining about being unable to run the game, but there are a number of fixes for the issue listed online. I initially had the same problem, but after running the game as an administrator and fiddling around with a few of the game's settings, I was able to get the game working and haven't had any problems since.As far as the game goes, the level design is impressive--many of the areas still look nice, despite the outdated graphics. The dialogue can be hokey at times, and it's important to keep in mind that the game is not at all an accurate representation of Chinese culture and narrative. The levelling and customization system is not as deep as other RPG's, but overall combat is fun and more oriented toward the Action RPG genre than KOTOR. There's a really excellent mod called Jade Empire In Style that adds a lot more depth to the game's combat and customization system if players feel like the vanilla version isn't satisfying enough. The story, while far from perfect and full of cliches, is good enough to keep the player engaged and interested in what will happen next. My biggest complaint about the game mechanics is the morality system--it is apparent that Bioware was attempting to make a morality system that was less about good vs. evil, and more about whether or not the ends justify the means. If this system were to have been implemented correctly, it would be possible to take the path of the "closed fist" without being an evil jerk. Unfortunately, despite a fair amount of dialogue in the game about how neither "path" is inherently evil, it's not really possible to follow the way of the closed fist without being a really terrible excuse for a human being.Right now I'm far from beating the game, so I can't comment on the ending, but despite it's flaws it's been a very enjoyable RPG.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												You probaly are looking at a lot of negative reviews about this game regarding the luancher and that can be easily fixed with a youtube or forum search on steam. My problem however is that this game wasn't exactly what I was expecting. I love bioware games, they are some of the best western rpg developers and there is some positive things about this game. This game for its time was beautiful and the character/enviroment designs are extremly well done for a 2007 port. The voice work as usual is very good and there are some great character designs in this game. It has widescreen/higher resolution support and you can even play with a controller.  However I couldn't help but feel that the story lacked a little bit compared to what I was use to in a bioware game. I say that becuase I felt the stories in thier other games like knights of the old republic, mass effect and the older dragon age games had more depth. When it went on sale for $3.75 I was estatic, however the more I played it I couldn't help but feel that I had to force myself to keep playing. In a sense I felt underwhelmed and lost interest the more I played it. Also there was some stuttering present even after the suggested fixes were applied and there was this horrible random camera glitch that occured more than 6 times during my play through were you got a birds eye view and couldnt see your character or see where you were going. The games difficulty was surprizingly hard and I felt like I needed to save alot, something you will need to do a lot of in this game. The combat system is fun and creative, but that was not enough to keep my interest. Bottom line is that if you came off of knights of the old republic or any of bioware's older rpgs, you might need to lower your expectations for this one to truly enjoy it. Despite some of the postive things I said, I couldn't in good spirits recommend this game. Fun fact though is that it does have some mods on modb.overall a  7.2/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Jade Empire is an essential Bioware roleplaying experience.  I prefer it to earlier offerings like Baldur's Gate because their creative team realized their own fantasy world from the ground up.  It sucessfully blends the tropes and conventions of classic wire flying films and asian folktales in what feels like a love letter to the genre.As I write this the JE is almost ten years old and examining it reveals a prototype for the story driven/ action rpgs like DA and ME that would follow.  It is a sweeping tale that that places the player in the familiar role of the "chosen one" whose actions will shape the course of the entire world as they chart their own personal destiny.  If this were a tabletop rpg I would hate this contrived convention but it works quite well in a single player video game. My only complaint is that the PC version seems to respond more sluggishly to controller input than the console version that I played when it relased in 04.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												The game itself is pretty good, its a lot like other Bioware games in its focus on character and story with decent RPG and combat mechanics. The Asian setting is refreshingly unusual for a western RPG and overall its a game well worth playing, not one of Biowares best but that is a high bar to reach. Unfortunately this version is extremely difficult to get working on a 64bit OS. I have tried to install it on windows 7 and windows 8.1 and it failed to work on either without quite a bit of surfing forum posts for solutions, most of which didn't help in the slightest as every OS seems to have a range of problems running this game and finding the solution for my particular problem "Application Error: Steam failed to start" (despite steam running at the time) was difficult to say the least. Eventually I got it working by copying the Steam.dll from the main Steam folder ( C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam  - on my system) and replacing the Steam.dll file in the game folder ( C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\SteamApps\common\Jade Empire - on my system) with it.There is no guarantee that this fix will work for anyone else but it seems so ridiculously simple a fix that its just appalling the publisher hasn't bothered to fix it themselves. In addition the configuration utility, that you are forced to use, is simply broken on windows 7 and 8 but the game tries to force you to use it anyway. This requiredme to rename JadeEmpireLauncher.exe to something else (e.g. JadeEmpireLauncher_BACKUP.exe) and rename JadeEmpire.exe to JadeEmpireLauncher.exe.If you're happy to mess around with this like I did then the game itself is good, but for the amount of effort put in over two separate OS's and no guarantee that it will function on a third I can't really recommend buying it from steam until these problems are fixed (and seeing as these problems have been around for years and the developer is now owned by a different publisher its almost certain that they will never be fixed).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												This is easily one of my favourite games of all time. A story-driven RPG, with the usual Bioware morality scale, only far less black-and-white, good-and-evil, and more to do with the actual ethics of characters, rather than "GOOD GUY HELP EVERYONE AND FART RAINBOWS, BAD GUY EAT PUPPIES AND SET EVERYTHING ON FIRE". Think Star Wars (Especially since this came out around the same time as they were working on the Knights Of The Old Republic games), the 'Open-Palm' path is basically the Jedi to the more Sith-like 'Closed-Fist'.I may be slightly biased due to my love of martial arts and mythology, but this game is rich with both, so I don't care, it's great.It's basically like being the major protagonist of a fantasy, kung-fu, cult-classic movie, for 20+ hours. There are demons, spirits, gods, ghosts, assassins, pirates, heavenly plains, and so many other things that I can't mention without spoilers.There are a lot of comments and reviews and whatnot for this game saying that it's not playable, or it's broken, and that it's all Steam's fault everyone is awful wah I'm a big whiny man-baby. It's not broken. If you're not an idiot. This game is nearly a decade old. It needs a little help to be able to run on newer computers. If you're on Windows 7, you will need to go into the game files, right-click on the "Jade Empire" application, go into the compatibility settings and set to run with Windows XP compatibility. There, I fixed it, now stop complaining.BUY IT. PLAY IT. IT'S GREAT.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												I originally owned this on the xbox and completed it at least three times. It's a great RPG and incredibly underrated. The story is a bit cliche but fun and the combat is excellent. One could argue that this game with the real time combat was a blue print for what Bioware would eventually do in the upcoming Mass Effect games. I love this game and wish more people could get into it...unfortunately the steam version doesn't do this title any favors. I cannot recommend this title through steam as it is a hassle to get working. There are several steps you have to go through just to get the damn game to load. Once that's done you may experience problems with in game cut scenes and the music going out of sync. After about 30 minutes of editing and doing some homework through google I got everything working, but the fact that people need to go through all this effort is  totally stupid. I also noticed that you can play the game with the gamepad. I gave it a shot for nostalgia, and it's functional but the auto targeting system is a mess. For any newcomers interested in this title, unless you're willing to take a chance and have some decent PC skills, try and give it a shot, but only if the game is dirt cheap on sale. For everyone else, I've been told the GOG version of Jade Empire runs fine without any problems, so you may want to check them out instead. Steam really needs to pay more attention to the games it offers its customers.

Jade Empire is quite unique among PC rpg-s: It allows you to travel to a fantasy conceived ancient China and engage in a thrilling-deepest story with multiple choices, gorgeous scenery, absorbing figures of local mythology (spirits, demons, dragons etc), emotionally soothing specific music...ans great steampunk settings. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 1, 2012
												Being Bioware's lightest RPG experience in their entire game library, Jade Empire most definitely stands out, if not only for that but also for delving into a setting rarely explored by western developers - that of Ancient China, albeit a fantasy version of one. Playing like an action RPG it is somewhat held back by its imprecise controls, one-note characters and simplistic mechanics, but overcomes these problems with an interesting setting, mere fact that it's a rare martial arts RPG and a genuine story twist. And in the end, it's easily one of the most underrated games Bioware has ever put out, but definitely worth your time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 6, 2013
												This game is one of Bioware's earlier RPGs before Mass Effect and Dragon Age modern fame.  Like a lot of developers, all their works share similar themes.  Good characterization, good humor, binary good / evil (although in this case its styled differently), good voice acting, etc.  The setting and music are characterization are all good and very well enjoyable, and quite amusing at times.  Bioware is very good at that, and I applaud them.The problem with the game is that the actual -game- portion is just not very fun.  The combat is downright awful because there is no balance or flow.  Most enemies could be button-mashed to death, and those that can't usually have some sort of rediculous advantage over the player such as no hitstun, extremely high damage, or extremely high health.  There are two types of MP, one for magic + healing and the other for weapons + bullet time... but considering that there is no other way to restore your health aside from generous cutscenes I can't see magic being useful.  Leveling up a weapon style makes it use almost no MP but bullet time drains MP like pouring water out of a cup.  Animations are VERY clunky and often uncancelable, and each style only has one combo and one guardbreak attack.  Controlling your character in fights is a pain because being locked on to an enemy makes you extremely slow, and free camera makes it impossible to hit enemies reliably.Levelling up gives points to spend in combat styles and other points to spend on stats, but there's no way to really know if you're going to get a good style later down the line and spent points are permanent.  Its a pitfall of RPGs, not knowing how well-spent your resources are because of a lack of transparency in the system.  Luckily stats are more easily corrected as you can swap equipment to boost the little used conversation stats and your primary stats, but nothing boosts your damage or defense directly.There are scant few puzzles in the game that really only pad or are otherwise obnoxious (get out a pen and paper because you'll need to memorize), and a seemingly pointless Galaga minigame that occurs often and produces no non-Galage related rewards.The game runs fine on Win7 / HD6850 / 3.2GHz * 6 / 8gb RAM system.  Its was made for the original XBOX and it shows, but the game controls perfectly fine on PC as a port even in the few fixed camera scenes.  I'd say pass on the game unless you like Bioware titles or the asian setting.  The combat in the game holds the whole package back far too much to be a robust title.  It's not worth suffering through for the story, which is only okay, even if well presented.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												I really feel like I should bother to write a review for this game. Back in the days, I used to play this game quite a lot on my Xbox, so I was really excited when I realized that this game was also getting released on Steam. First off, let me address all the people saying that they could not get this game to run on Win7 and above. I myself also use Win7 and have played it multiple times without even a single glitch or bug. The game runs just as smoothly as it did on my console, if not even smoother. And if you had sacrificed a mere two minutes of your lives searching for a solution to the infamous "Steam not found"-error you would be able to enjoy this game in its entirety as well. For those too thick-headed to look it up themselves: a) Either replace the JadeLauncher.exe with the JadeEmpire.exe orb) add your Steam directory as a path in Win7 (and above). It really is not that hard, guys. But enough with the whining. I came here to write a review about the game and this is what I will do. I'd really like to compose some kind of list of the pros and cons of the game but unfortunately, I cannot think of anything that'd fall into the latter category. Even though this game might not be up to the modern-day graphics standard (also meaning that there is no HD remake ... yet), the game makes up for it with an intense and engaging story, an entertaining combat system and a wide variety of different combat styles and techniques. The choice, as with many Bioware titles, is complely up to you: Whether you prefer the classic martial arts, like the brute force of a wide arsenal of different melee and (one...) ranged weapons, fancy being a ranged spellcaster or even prefer to transform into a various amount of demons to squish your foes in an instant, the game does offer you every single one of these possibilities. The choices you make on your way to your ultimate goal do, of course, affect how the story develops and how the people react to you. There are the two big classic sides of good (the so-called Way of the Open Palm) and bad (The Closed Fist). Depending on those you gain different trinkets and skills and shape the climax of the game. But you don't have to travel alone. The game helps you out with several companions, each one with an interesting back story and unique abilities. Don't like dragging someone along the whole time who is only getting in the way? It's not a problem! Almost every companion has two different ways to aid you in combat: Attack and support. But I do have to say that most of the compnions fancy you being the nice guy, so you might have a hard time dealing with them when walking the dark path. Unfortunately, there are some techniques in the game that cannot be accessed and learnt during the game (and of course, these are mostly only the cool ones). Nevertheless, some talented modder thought of a solution to this problem and released the best and most popular mod for Jade Empire: Jade in Style. If you already know the game and are looking for a little more variation in styles you should certainly check out this mod. The world of Jade Empire seems somewhat like a mashup of many different clichés of medival Asia but it really doesn't matter after the first few minutes of gameplay. Sadly, you cannot explore most areas - the game basically tells you where to go and the progression through the different areas is rather linear, especially when entering a dungeon. I'd really like to talk about its main feature - the story. But I won't because I do not want to spoil anything and I am not quite sure I would be able to say something different than "OMG, it's so epic!!" (you get the gist). Let me just say that the game contained the most WTF plot twist of my childhood. So, in conclusion, I'd like to say that I highly recommend this game. I have by far not talked about all the features this game offers because I feel that some things should be yours to discover.Once you get it to run, the whole experience is at least as good as it was "in the olden days". It even offers full (Xbox) controller support, but is just easy to play with a mouse and a keyboard (it's what I did). I hope that a few of you will not be deterred by the vast amount of negative reviews regarding the PC adaption because it really is a very good game.But go and see for yourselves!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Quality Bioware from a time before EA. The game plays and unfolds in a typical bioware (back then bioware) fashion with the same sort of humble beginings and story twists you would hope to be suprised by. They are effective in making an Asian-influenced world with a fun and unique combat system based on real-time kung-fu combos and a sort of chi magic. Overall, it feels like an experiment for trying out many of the features and ideas they would make into Knights of the Old Republic. While feeling more shallow than KOTOR it still manages to entertain and should'nt be missed if you liked the original KOTOR or like kung-fu movies.

												The first Bioware game I ever played. Easily one of my all time favorites. It has a rather rich Wuxia setting, and a pretty unique combat system/style based on kung fu, wushu, and other arts found in Wuxia lore. But beside that, just stating "It is an adventure in a mythological ancient China, made by Bioware" should tell enough to anyone familiar with that company.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												This is easily one of my favourite games of all time. A story-driven RPG, with the usual Bioware morality scale, only far less black-and-white, good-and-evil, and more to do with the actual ethics of characters, rather than "GOOD GUY HELP EVERYONE AND FART RAINBOWS, BAD GUY EAT PUPPIES AND SET EVERYTHING ON FIRE". Think Star Wars (Especially since this came out around the same time as they were working on the Knights Of The Old Republic games), the 'Open-Palm' path is basically the Jedi to the more Sith-like 'Closed-Fist'.I may be slightly biased due to my love of martial arts and mythology, but this game is rich with both, so I don't care, it's great.It's basically like being the major protagonist of a fantasy, kung-fu, cult-classic movie, for 20+ hours. There are demons, spirits, gods, ghosts, assassins, pirates, heavenly plains, and so many other things that I can't mention without spoilers.There are a lot of comments and reviews and whatnot for this game saying that it's not playable, or it's broken, and that it's all Steam's fault everyone is awful wah I'm a big whiny man-baby. It's not broken. If you're not an idiot. This game is nearly a decade old. It needs a little help to be able to run on newer computers. If you're on Windows 7, you will need to go into the game files, right-click on the "Jade Empire" application, go into the compatibility settings and set to run with Windows XP compatibility. There, I fixed it, now stop complaining.BUY IT. PLAY IT. IT'S GREAT.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												I originally owned this on the xbox and completed it at least three times. It's a great RPG and incredibly underrated. The story is a bit cliche but fun and the combat is excellent. One could argue that this game with the real time combat was a blue print for what Bioware would eventually do in the upcoming Mass Effect games. I love this game and wish more people could get into it...unfortunately the steam version doesn't do this title any favors. I cannot recommend this title through steam as it is a hassle to get working. There are several steps you have to go through just to get the damn game to load. Once that's done you may experience problems with in game cut scenes and the music going out of sync. After about 30 minutes of editing and doing some homework through google I got everything working, but the fact that people need to go through all this effort is  totally stupid. I also noticed that you can play the game with the gamepad. I gave it a shot for nostalgia, and it's functional but the auto targeting system is a mess. For any newcomers interested in this title, unless you're willing to take a chance and have some decent PC skills, try and give it a shot, but only if the game is dirt cheap on sale. For everyone else, I've been told the GOG version of Jade Empire runs fine without any problems, so you may want to check them out instead. Steam really needs to pay more attention to the games it offers its customers.

												Plotting and predictible this game is an extremely generic bioware game wrapped in a very interesting shell. Every second you play this game you will want to be playing the exact same game except done better.Combat is slow, clunky, unbalanced, and clumsy and the second you fight enemies who can outright ignore your attacks you will yell foul as they become undefeatable without very specific strategies.What the game does right is create its world and mythology where even the philsophical nature of ethics is different from our own, albiet with the standard Bioware silly morality systems. The martial arts are diverse and interesting and some even awe inspiring. Sometimes you will just want to continue with the game just to see what you will get next and that is when the game is doing its best.Overall this game is a solid 6/10 I probably most want to see done right.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												This game is KOTOR in Little big Chinatown. It's more homage to the Chinese Marital-art house asthetic than an RPG set in a faithflly re-created Ancient China, which will hit you as soon as the Steampunk technology comes into play.If you've played the Bioware Knights franchise, this game will feel right at home to you. The dialogue system, the alignment system, the influence over companions, etc. is all inherited from the 1st game.The only serious deviation is askewing of realtime-turn-based combat, for 3rd person combat. You click, and your character attacks, you can move and manuever your character at will.There is also a shoot-em' up mini-game which, at times I think clashes with the rest of the game in tone, but otherwise is memorable where most of BIoware's mini games were either boring or insufferable.Perhaps the most memorable feature to this game? The Cast. Alot of star power arrived for this outing, Nathan Fillion, Brian Doyle Murray, Armin Shimerman, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly John Cleese, and anyone whose played adapation titles like Devil May Cry or Final Fantasy 9 or Armored Core 4 will recognize Kari Wahlgren.I honestly can't recommend this game enough, but be warned, Imperfect Customer has it right, you do need to mess with some files inorder to get the game both to work, and for your cursor (the mouse pointer) to appear.If you're experiencing this problem download this file and put it into your Jade Empire directory:https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/22012712/JadeEmpireLauncher.exeIt's an old Jade Empire exe renamed "JadeEmpireLauncher" so steam will launch it instead of the launcher which can end in error. You still need to launch the game from Steam though, clicking on it won't do anything. Your Jade Empire Directory can be found in Steam-> SteamApps -> Common-> Jade Empire.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												I really feel like I should bother to write a review for this game. Back in the days, I used to play this game quite a lot on my Xbox, so I was really excited when I realized that this game was also getting released on Steam. First off, let me address all the people saying that they could not get this game to run on Win7 and above. I myself also use Win7 and have played it multiple times without even a single glitch or bug. The game runs just as smoothly as it did on my console, if not even smoother. And if you had sacrificed a mere two minutes of your lives searching for a solution to the infamous "Steam not found"-error you would be able to enjoy this game in its entirety as well. For those too thick-headed to look it up themselves: a) Either replace the JadeLauncher.exe with the JadeEmpire.exe orb) add your Steam directory as a path in Win7 (and above). It really is not that hard, guys. But enough with the whining. I came here to write a review about the game and this is what I will do. I'd really like to compose some kind of list of the pros and cons of the game but unfortunately, I cannot think of anything that'd fall into the latter category. Even though this game might not be up to the modern-day graphics standard (also meaning that there is no HD remake ... yet), the game makes up for it with an intense and engaging story, an entertaining combat system and a wide variety of different combat styles and techniques. The choice, as with many Bioware titles, is complely up to you: Whether you prefer the classic martial arts, like the brute force of a wide arsenal of different melee and (one...) ranged weapons, fancy being a ranged spellcaster or even prefer to transform into a various amount of demons to squish your foes in an instant, the game does offer you every single one of these possibilities. The choices you make on your way to your ultimate goal do, of course, affect how the story develops and how the people react to you. There are the two big classic sides of good (the so-called Way of the Open Palm) and bad (The Closed Fist). Depending on those you gain different trinkets and skills and shape the climax of the game. But you don't have to travel alone. The game helps you out with several companions, each one with an interesting back story and unique abilities. Don't like dragging someone along the whole time who is only getting in the way? It's not a problem! Almost every companion has two different ways to aid you in combat: Attack and support. But I do have to say that most of the compnions fancy you being the nice guy, so you might have a hard time dealing with them when walking the dark path. Unfortunately, there are some techniques in the game that cannot be accessed and learnt during the game (and of course, these are mostly only the cool ones). Nevertheless, some talented modder thought of a solution to this problem and released the best and most popular mod for Jade Empire: Jade in Style. If you already know the game and are looking for a little more variation in styles you should certainly check out this mod. The world of Jade Empire seems somewhat like a mashup of many different clichés of medival Asia but it really doesn't matter after the first few minutes of gameplay. Sadly, you cannot explore most areas - the game basically tells you where to go and the progression through the different areas is rather linear, especially when entering a dungeon. I'd really like to talk about its main feature - the story. But I won't because I do not want to spoil anything and I am not quite sure I would be able to say something different than "OMG, it's so epic!!" (you get the gist). Let me just say that the game contained the most WTF plot twist of my childhood. So, in conclusion, I'd like to say that I highly recommend this game. I have by far not talked about all the features this game offers because I feel that some things should be yours to discover.Once you get it to run, the whole experience is at least as good as it was "in the olden days". It even offers full (Xbox) controller support, but is just easy to play with a mouse and a keyboard (it's what I did). I hope that a few of you will not be deterred by the vast amount of negative reviews regarding the PC adaption because it really is a very good game.But go and see for yourselves!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												If you are a fan of Fable or Knights of the Old Republic, you will definitely enjoy this game.For starters, the combat has a very Fable Like feel. Same as the non-open world aspect of it, which I personally enjoy. It's easy to know where you've explored and what you've accomplished. Also, the map markers which indicate where you need to go or where the individual you must seek out are very easy to understand.The dialogue is exactly how Knights of the Old Republic works. The main story is very well done and it keeps you wanting more, the downside is your companions. I didn't feel as connected or as interested in them as I did with the Old Republic. I felt Bioware let us down very much in that aspect. There are few times were you can really even talk to each individual member. Also, the fact you only get one companion at a time adds to that. Romancing, also. I enjoyed that quite a bit in Old Repulic because I felt a deeper connection between the characters. Word of advice, be VERY careful of what you say. I said one wrong thing early in the game and ruined my chances completely. Overall, if you're looking for a deeper connection towards the individual characters, you will not, imo, be as concerned with these guys as in KotOR. That being said, it is good on it's own merits.Dialogue, some of the dialogue is very tedious and made me lose interest. It didn't have to much to do with the story at times and the lore was subpar. The documents and scrolls which you read are the main highlights in opinion. Very well written and nicely done.The combat is awesome. It takes a bit to get used too, but once you do it's a breeze. Multiple styles to learn make it quite an enjoyable experience. Also, leveling is a lot simpler as well. I simply balanced every time I leveled and all the gems I received by the end of the game made it a cake walk.The lack of changing armor was a bit dissapointing and really lacked customization. Also weapons, though there are an abundant of fighting styles. Weapons are almost next to non-existent. That is one thing you have to look out for when leveling, your skill points. If you waste the few you get throughout the game on a weapon you won't use much later, you will have quite a bit of trouble.Now the story. It consists of 7 chapters. The first 4 chapters are very thoroughly done and constists of an abundant amount of side quests, which in all reality, aren't too important. They mainly give you pointless gems that are much too weak. It's even worse if you are Open Palm, because you're not taking any rewards. After 4, all side quests drop immedietaly. They are very rushed and seemed to cram all the story into those last 3, so it kind of feels like you are being jipped out of content. Again comparing it to the Old Republic, the worlds on that game were huge and provided quite a bit of content. There are only 3 villages you visit in this game, and almost no one to talk to beside quest givers.Overall, for what it is, it's wonderful. The Old Republic scaled down with a different way of combat, much like Fable. The story has it's twists and turns but feels rushed towards the end. The lack of connection I felt to the characters was a bit upsetting but the wonderful graphics of it's time and smooth gameplay, especially during fights make up for it. It's a good 15-25 hour game and replay value is great especially if you want to go Open Palm or Closed Fist.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												If you like Bioware-style RPGs, definitely consider getting this game--especially if it's on sale. A lot of folks have been complaining about being unable to run the game, but there are a number of fixes for the issue listed online. I initially had the same problem, but after running the game as an administrator and fiddling around with a few of the game's settings, I was able to get the game working and haven't had any problems since.As far as the game goes, the level design is impressive--many of the areas still look nice, despite the outdated graphics. The dialogue can be hokey at times, and it's important to keep in mind that the game is not at all an accurate representation of Chinese culture and narrative. The levelling and customization system is not as deep as other RPG's, but overall combat is fun and more oriented toward the Action RPG genre than KOTOR. There's a really excellent mod called Jade Empire In Style that adds a lot more depth to the game's combat and customization system if players feel like the vanilla version isn't satisfying enough. The story, while far from perfect and full of cliches, is good enough to keep the player engaged and interested in what will happen next. My biggest complaint about the game mechanics is the morality system--it is apparent that Bioware was attempting to make a morality system that was less about good vs. evil, and more about whether or not the ends justify the means. If this system were to have been implemented correctly, it would be possible to take the path of the "closed fist" without being an evil jerk. Unfortunately, despite a fair amount of dialogue in the game about how neither "path" is inherently evil, it's not really possible to follow the way of the closed fist without being a really terrible excuse for a human being.Right now I'm far from beating the game, so I can't comment on the ending, but despite it's flaws it's been a very enjoyable RPG.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												One thing I love about video games is their ability to make me feel special. In this world where most of us are - face it - pretty ordinary, it's great to be able to spend some time in a fictional place where you feel like you are truly making a difference. And in Jade Empire, this is not just a feeling that dawns on you when the credits start rolling. It's there from the very first minutes, and stays with you throughout the game.Jade Empire is a typical, if slightly aged BioWare RPG. You can play the game in different ways depending on your preferences, and there are plenty of interesting characters to interact with. I wasn't too fond of a few companions initially, but they ended up growing on me. By the end of the game, I was happy to have all of them by my side.On the downside, I ran into a bug that made the camera point at the floor a little more often than I'd like. This seemed to happen randomly and was pretty effective at breaking my immersion, but it could be fixed by saving and reloading.This game is not as famous as most other BioWare RPGs (think SW:KOTOR, Mass Effect or Dragon Age), but it is interesting and unique in its own way, especially due to the Asian setting. Although not quite at the level of those blockbuster games, Jade Empire is more than worth your time.

												The game is worth getting if you have a Windows XP. The people that are having problems getting this to work seem to have Windows Vista, 7, or 8. I have an XP and a 7, and the game works just fine on the XP. Although you may run into a config error starting the game up, but it has an easy fix. Just go to the Jade Empire folder and rename the launcher to "JadeEmpireLauncherBackup", and then rename the Jade Empire .exe to "JadeEmpireLauncher", and thats all. The game so far is quite worth it. If you've ever played Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic I and II, it has very similar gameplay to that.
