content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												A gem of an Old Bioware game! I had no idea before I actually tried it. I have no idea any longer why I hadn't tried it and I can only wonder why it hasn't meritted more attention as an intellectual property.The story, pacing, and other such plot elements are, to my taste, legit in comparison to other Old Bioware titles like Knights of the Old Republic and Baldur's Gates. Happily, it was one of those RPG stories I was not expecting to get caught up in and which I was memorably rapt and engaged to explore my first playthrough. Several of the side characters are memorable, the rest being amply adequate, and the romance subplots are nice enough. Appreciable world building polishes like an original language are interesting and, in my opinion, respectable artistic investments. For RPG completionists, there is to be divined (I have done so) a long enough but not too long set of missable items, etc.,  to hunt up. Certainly the character customization and development available here is nothing to Neverwinter Nights (and the same are far and away the most attractive aspects of NWN) and the martial arts dynamics are (presumably) little match for actual fighting games. But I found both highly satisfying in their simplicity. It's a sweetly elegant and intuitive simplicity, not an underwhelming simplicity, in my opinion, and to the extent that I reckon it a major asset of the design.Overall, I've continually considered Jade Empire an unique and highly pleasant flavor to occasionally crave.Get the mod Jade Empire in Style! With it and its rebalance in favor of proficiency in numerous styles, my replayability has gained significantly from the opportunity to gain more and finer combat skills through assessing the complements of combinations of single styles. I.e., trying the general pros and cons of the several main styles was interesting enough for several plays through, and with the expanded style list trying the very finest nuances of the combined pros and cons of switching several styles dynamically in battle is much stimulating, for me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												Jade Empire is an immersive 3rd person game with an emphasis on story and martial arts - themed combat. JE was published and developed by BioWare, which many may recognize as the company under EA which is known to deliver on immersive, story rich games which often include innovative gameplay mechanics, such as the Mass Effect or Dragon Age series. Jade Empire is no exception, as the fighting is very rewarding and, surprisingly, does not get repetitive nearly as fast as you might expect it to. Different martial arts styles are very distinctive from one another, although certain martial arts and weapon styles outshine others, which means most players may opt out of changing styles due to the success they have with a certain one. Decision-making is a pivotal part of the game. The decisions you make will branch the story out to a certain extent, affect how characters react to you and also affect the ending too. Jade Empire's story is long and immersive. You take the role of a student in a martial arts school lead by your mentor, Master Li. You can choose your character from a selection of different toons, either going with a pre-selected loadout (Starting styles and stats, like in many MMORPGs) or making your own loadout. Your own character isn't voice acted, which is a shame, but it's not that big of a deal. Jade Empire is quite a long game and it takes you through various cities, villages and wildernesses throughout China. The game has a companion system, which lets you be accompanied by one character out of many others who you meet on your journey. You can switch out companions at nearly any time you wish, as they all follow you during your journey in the background. (Appearing in a camp when not selected). The story takes many turns and if you are into Chinese mythology or history, you will definitely enjoy Jade Empire. The game is a bit old, but it is not it's fault and I still warmly recommend it to anyone. It requires some patience from the player to listen to the narrative and get immersed in the story, as all BioWare games do anyway. In my opinion, the combat is very fun and rewarding, as for some bosses and enemies you really have to plan ahead and switch styles during the fight in order to survive. The characters and the plot are what shine in the game the most for me. Some provide comic relief, some provide moral guidance for the decisions you must make during your journey, and some work to intrigue you and astonish you. My favorite character is hands down is Henpecked Hou, an awkward chef who acts as comic relief by complaining about how he will get beat up by his wife and who also provides a unique drunken martial style by throwing wine bottles at you during combat. A great guy indeed.All in all, there is only one thing that I can think of that Jade Empire really, really needs. A sequel. Seriously. The game has a great story as long as you have the patience to play through it. The game is great and the main factor that makes it great is that there aren't many games like it out here in Steam.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												I originally owned this on the xbox and completed it at least three times. It's a great RPG and incredibly underrated. The story is a bit cliche but fun and the combat is excellent. One could argue that this game with the real time combat was a blue print for what Bioware would eventually do in the upcoming Mass Effect games. I love this game and wish more people could get into it...unfortunately the steam version doesn't do this title any favors. I cannot recommend this title through steam as it is a hassle to get working. There are several steps you have to go through just to get the damn game to load. Once that's done you may experience problems with in game cut scenes and the music going out of sync. After about 30 minutes of editing and doing some homework through google I got everything working, but the fact that people need to go through all this effort is  totally stupid. I also noticed that you can play the game with the gamepad. I gave it a shot for nostalgia, and it's functional but the auto targeting system is a mess. For any newcomers interested in this title, unless you're willing to take a chance and have some decent PC skills, try and give it a shot, but only if the game is dirt cheap on sale. For everyone else, I've been told the GOG version of Jade Empire runs fine without any problems, so you may want to check them out instead. Steam really needs to pay more attention to the games it offers its customers.

Posted: February 27, 2011
												A classic Bioware title, in the mould of Knights of the Old Republic and Mass Effect. This is probably the most original RPG I've played; they created their own universe loosely based on the myths of ancient China and Japan, and invented a language with it. The musical score is absolutely beautiful too. As for the story, you can decide to be good or evil, or something in between, and the decisions you make impact the ending as well as what happens to the characters you meet.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Quality Bioware from a time before EA. The game plays and unfolds in a typical bioware (back then bioware) fashion with the same sort of humble beginings and story twists you would hope to be suprised by. They are effective in making an Asian-influenced world with a fun and unique combat system based on real-time kung-fu combos and a sort of chi magic. Overall, it feels like an experiment for trying out many of the features and ideas they would make into Knights of the Old Republic. While feeling more shallow than KOTOR it still manages to entertain and should'nt be missed if you liked the original KOTOR or like kung-fu movies.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 6, 2013
												This game is one of Bioware's earlier RPGs before Mass Effect and Dragon Age modern fame.  Like a lot of developers, all their works share similar themes.  Good characterization, good humor, binary good / evil (although in this case its styled differently), good voice acting, etc.  The setting and music are characterization are all good and very well enjoyable, and quite amusing at times.  Bioware is very good at that, and I applaud them.The problem with the game is that the actual -game- portion is just not very fun.  The combat is downright awful because there is no balance or flow.  Most enemies could be button-mashed to death, and those that can't usually have some sort of rediculous advantage over the player such as no hitstun, extremely high damage, or extremely high health.  There are two types of MP, one for magic + healing and the other for weapons + bullet time... but considering that there is no other way to restore your health aside from generous cutscenes I can't see magic being useful.  Leveling up a weapon style makes it use almost no MP but bullet time drains MP like pouring water out of a cup.  Animations are VERY clunky and often uncancelable, and each style only has one combo and one guardbreak attack.  Controlling your character in fights is a pain because being locked on to an enemy makes you extremely slow, and free camera makes it impossible to hit enemies reliably.Levelling up gives points to spend in combat styles and other points to spend on stats, but there's no way to really know if you're going to get a good style later down the line and spent points are permanent.  Its a pitfall of RPGs, not knowing how well-spent your resources are because of a lack of transparency in the system.  Luckily stats are more easily corrected as you can swap equipment to boost the little used conversation stats and your primary stats, but nothing boosts your damage or defense directly.There are scant few puzzles in the game that really only pad or are otherwise obnoxious (get out a pen and paper because you'll need to memorize), and a seemingly pointless Galaga minigame that occurs often and produces no non-Galage related rewards.The game runs fine on Win7 / HD6850 / 3.2GHz * 6 / 8gb RAM system.  Its was made for the original XBOX and it shows, but the game controls perfectly fine on PC as a port even in the few fixed camera scenes.  I'd say pass on the game unless you like Bioware titles or the asian setting.  The combat in the game holds the whole package back far too much to be a robust title.  It's not worth suffering through for the story, which is only okay, even if well presented.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												I am writing this review for the Steam Awards badge. this does not make my review any less true, merely horribly overdue.I nominated Jade Empire for the custom category Hiddem Gem, because it is one. When it was first released it received great reviews, but the sales figures never matched that, probably because it was new and different.It is set in an Asian setting and draws heavily on eastern mythology. Then it allows you to beat said mythology up with magic, martial arts (including backflips and other acrobatic stunts) and several weapons. Or you can choose to talk it out in true RPG fashion. It also has a morality system with two sides that are not exactly good or evil, but more like yin and yang. Nobody will really judge you for it either since the way of the Closed Fist and the way of the Open Palm are established philosophies within the game. If you feel bad or uncomfortable making some of the choices then maybe one of those philosophies is just not for you.I found the story to be ok. It goes on for longer than I expected the first time and if you take the time to look for them it actually has several interesting little tidbits hidden away. This includes the possibility of beating up a "British" person.Give it a try.

												Pros+ Excellent story and progression+ Likeable characters and companions+ Interesting lore+ Immersive soundtrack+ Acceptable graphics for a 10+ year old game+ Moderate customizability for character classes+ Morality/karma system adds some personalityCons- Too few locations/towns to visit- Cumbersome and frustrating combat (in my opinion)- Companions are often useless in combat- Some areas of the game can feel repetitive or boringNotes1. Gameplay is reminiscent of other Bioware titles such as KoTOR and Dragon Age: Origins with added innovation2. Character appearance is selected at the start and cannot be modified or customized in any way3. While using spells requires "mana" as one would expect, using weapons also requires a kind of energy which drains with use

												One of the unsung greatest games ever made. More than any game I have played, I wish there could have been more, and I wish they had made another one. 												Don't be fooled by the playtime; I've played the xbox version.Jade Empire is such an underrated game and as Bioware's first original IP, it deserves a bit more respect. It doesn't have anything on a lot of their other games, sure, but I have good memories. I had a great story, great characters and an interesting setting for an RPG. The only minor complaints I have is that the PC version is a little buggy in comparison to the xbox version (and I played this game on a 360 with backwards compatibility too). content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												This isn't a bad game. I didn't really know that it was met with luke-warm feelings by gamers far and wide. I watched someone play it initially, and I thought it was pretty cool. It ran pretty badly on my computer, but the glitches aren't game breaking; mostly just a minor irritation as you would have to reload to get the game to work again. However, the storyline isn't uninteresting. The graphics aren't entirely bad. It was fun and I played it through pretty quickly - and the themes of the story are pretty neat (the ghosts being restless, the water dragon's powers, etc.). However, you don't get to know your team very well and the fact that only one of them can follow you around is a little bit of a bummer. You can't really customize your character at all and it felt kind of 'meh' to me, too. Still, worth playing if you can get it on sale and you can get it to work.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												This is the game that got me into Bioware games. I have very fond memories playing this countless times on my original Xbox. The main story is well writen and the world beautiful. The characters and the majority of the side quests are interesting.  If you are a John Cleese fan, he does have a cameo in the game in one of the side quests. It still looks great on my computer as it did when I first played it on my original Xbox. I personaly feel, combat itself is what hurts it however. Each of the fighting styles has one heavy attack and one light attack with the same blocking animation, with no real combos. This can make the combat feel boring at times if you are only using one or two fighting styles. You will be wanting to increase the number of fighting styles and hotkeying them so it does not feel as repetitive.       I do prefer this version on my PC since the load times are not as bad as the version on my Xbox. However this copy took me a while to get it to work on my computer. I had to go threw countless troubleshooting and work arounds but eventualy I did get it to work.If you are a Bioware fan and enjoy RPG's I can easily recommend this game even though I went threw hell trying to get it to work.  It is a shame that this game is considered to be a commercial flop since I feel that it should have done better when it first came out.

I found a fix for it in the Steam community so it was an easy bypass once I finally found it.  I was finally able to finish the game today after being in my Steam library for about 2 years.Would recommend for people who want a good story and if you are patient with the combat.

												Pretty fun game, can't say I relate to the people here having problems launching the game because I went from start to end without hitting a bug or any kind of issue. Take it at face value though, just because I had a good experience it doesn't mean that yours will be too. Won't say it's worth 15€ (even though it's so good, it's an old game, at most it'd be worth 10€), so get it on sale if you can. Otherwise, ask someone to family share with you so you can try the game and see if it runs well!

												Really fun ancient asia style game. You get to do different kinds of martial arts and use chi and magics. Good voice acting and choices to make like in other Bioware games. Story is pretty interesting so far, drives me forward. Combat while not as fluid as some of the action adveture games like DMC or Bayonetta it's still fun and strategic. Getting different styles of fighting and having all these different followers is very cool.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												Jade Empire has to be one of my favorite games to play.  Yes, the port to PC is not perfect, but it's workable for the most part (it took a lot of uninstalling and reinstalling to finally get it to play), but it' a great game.  The story is fantastic and the setting is just beautiful.  Imagine what it would look like in HD.  I come back to this game time and time again because I fell in love with the characters and the story.  The combat is fun and not too challenging.  Give it a shot is my suggestion.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												The Controls for this games, specifically when it comes to the camera and movement, are designed for a WASD game like World of Warcraft, and not at all like they were on the original XBOX. People are saying that the GOG port is better, but they havent specified whether it fixes this issue or not. I would suggest avoiding the pc port of this game altogether, unfortunately. Perhaps they will fix is one day, if enough returns are made, But it's unlikely. Better look for a hard copy while you can.
